name: Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad
architects: A.C. Norman, R.A.J. Bidwell, A.B. Hubback
info: This iconic landmark was the grand administrative center for the British. Built with over 4 million bricks, its 41-meter clock tower houses a one-ton bell that first chimed for Queen Victoria's birthday in 1897. Look for the granite bollards by the porch—they were for tethering horses!

quiz.q: What was the cost of the building in Straits Dollars?

flyer_text: Constructed 1894-1897; Architects AC Norman, RAJ Bidwell, CE Spooner and AB Hubback (for the interior); Cost $198,000 (Straits Dollars). This was the Government Offices of the British Colonial administration. The original building, built in the shape of the letter E has a front façade facing the padang (this was the Parade Ground which is now called Dataran Merdeka). At 480ft in length, the two storey building has a wide arched colonnade running around both floors with seven staircases and a massive porch and entrance hall with its marble staircase in the centre. It was the largest building of its day, constructed entirely of brick and plaster. The imposing clock tower rises to over 140ft high with a copper dome and presents a dramatic setting for this historic civic quarter. The one-ton-bell clock was set to strike the hour and half hour and had a four-sided opal glass dial 8 feet in diameter. This clock was first heard during Queen Victoria's birthday parade in 1897. It was reported that over 4,000,000 bricks, 2,500 barrels of cement, 18,000 pikuls of lime, 4,000 cubic yards of sand, 5,000 lbs of copper, 50,000 tons of steel and iron, and about 30,000 cubic feet of timber were used in its construction.
ai_context:
This is perhaps the most famous landmark in Kuala Lumpur! It was the main Government Office for the British Colonial administration. Built for $198,000 Straits Dollars, it was the largest building of its day, constructed with over 4 million bricks.

Don't Miss: The imposing 41-meter (140ft) clock tower with its copper dome. It houses a one-ton bell that first chimed for Queen Victoria's birthday in 1897.

Look For: Near the main porch, you'll see the tops of granite bollards. These were originally used for tethering horses! They look sunken because the road level today is much higher than it was in the 1890s.

Fun Fact: The clock tower is often nicknamed the 'Big Ben of Malaysia' and was the centerpiece for the 1957 Merdeka (Independence) celebrations at the field opposite.

faq.tips: Come at night to see the building beautifully illuminated with colored lights. The best photo spot is across the street at Dataran Merdeka.

name: Old Post Office
info: Built for $100,000 Straits Dollars, this Moghul-style building served as KL's General Post Office until 1984. It was designed by A.B. Hubback to perfectly match its famous neighbor, the Sultan Abdul Samad Building, and features wide verandahs and elegant horse-shoe arches.

quiz.hint: His initials are A.B. He also designed Jamek Mosque.

flyer_text: Now used for the offices of Kementerian Pelancongan dan Kebudayaan (Ministry of Tourism and Culture). was built between 1904 and 1907. Designed by Architect AB Hubback and built at a cost of $100,000 (Straits Dollars), it remained the General Post Office until 1984 when the post office was relocated to the Dayabumi Complex. In 1991. the building was renovated and used as the Court of Appeal. The style of this building is similar to that of the Sultan Abdul Samad building, with wide arcaded verandahs of pointed horse-shoe arches. Pinnacles frame the central leaf design pediment which is best viewed from the Padang looking towards the building and the many sided stair towers flank both ends of this façade.
ai_context:
Designed by A.B. Hubback to perfectly complement its famous neighbor (Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad), this Moghul-style structure was KL's General Post Office until 1984. It cost $100,000 Straits Dollars to build.

Look For: It showcases Hubback's signature style with its wide, arcaded verandahs and elegant horse-shoe arches. The building is now used by the Ministry of Tourism and Culture.

Fun Fact: It was strategically built next to the old KL railway station, allowing mail to be processed and sorted efficiently as soon as it arrived in the city.

faq.tips: Take a photo of the building from the Padang looking towards the building and the many sided stair towers flank both ends of this façade.

name: Wisma Straits Trading & Loke Yew Building
architects: B.M. Iversen (Loke Yew), A.K. Moosden (Chow Kit)
info: This cluster of buildings tells the story of KL's commercial boom. The Loke Yew Building (1930s) is a famous Art Deco structure. Next door, the Chow Kit & Co. building (1905) shows off a Neo-Renaissance style with Flemish pediments. These represent the empires of tin tycoons like Loke Yew.

quiz.q: The Loke Yew Building is a 6-storey ___ style structure.
quiz.hint: A decorative style from the 1920s and 30s. Starts with 'A'.

flyer_text: The vehicular entrance to Wisma Straits Trading is from Jalan Mahkamah Tinggi, although its front faces Lebuh Pasar Besar. A pre-WW2 building, it went through a major refurbishment in the early 2000s and is now a seven storey modern building which houses many legal firms with retail on the ground floor. The Straits Trading Company was originally established by James Sword and Herman Mihlinghaus in 1887 the main point for delivery and sale of tin ore for export. It eventually became one of the largest tin smelters in the world. Towkay Loke Yew (b. 1846, d. 1917) was one of the first to send his ore to the Straits Trading Company and by 1901 he had built up a substantial holding and in 1906 he became a director of the company. Beside Wisma Straits Trading is the Loke Yew Building. The original three-storey building from the early 1900s at one time had housed John Little & Co, one of the earliest trading houses in the Straits Settlements. This iconic six-storey Art Deco style structure was designed by B.M. Iversen, who also was responsible for many other landmark buildings such as the Chinese Assembly Hall and the Federal House in Kuala Lumpur. Located at the intersection of Lebuh Pasar Besar and Jalan Makhamah Persekutuan, just before the bridge across the Klang River, have ensured that the two distinctive façades of the Loke Yew Building along remain very much part of the visual landscape of this part of the city. Immediately next door along the side of the Klang River is the Chow Kit & Co. Building. Built between 1904-1906 in Neo-Renaissance style it is believed to have been designed by AK Moosden who was also responsible for the elaborate designs of the block of shophouses on Market Square for Towkay Loke Yew. The Flemish type pediments and two arched-window bay windows of the Chow Kit & Co. Building show influences from the Low Countries in Europe.
ai_context:
This cluster tells the story of KL's commercial boom. The 6-storey Loke Yew Building is a famous example of the Art Deco style (a 1920s-30s style known for geometric forms), designed by B.M. Iversen. It once housed John Little & Co., one of the earliest trading houses.

Next door is the Chow Kit & Co. Building (1904-1906) in a Neo-Renaissance style. Look For: Its unique Flemish-style pediments (the triangular top of the building).

Fun Fact: The Loke Yew Building is named after Loke Yew, a business magnate and philanthropist who was one of the richest men in British Malaya and a director of the Straits Trading Company.

faq.opening_hours: Exterior viewable 24 hours. Offices are private.
faq.tips: Stand at the corner of Lebuh Pasar Besar to get a photo of the Loke Yew Building's curved Art Deco facade.

name: Masjid Jamek
info: Officially Masjid Jamek Sultan Abdul Samad, this is one of KL's oldest mosques. It's built at the historic confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers—the very birthplace of Kuala Lumpur! It sits on the site of an old Malay cemetery and features distinctive red and white brick bands.

quiz.q: Masjid Jamek is located on the site of a Malay...
quiz.hint: A place where the dead are buried.

flyer_text: Standing on the bridge at Lebuh Pasar Besar (originally called Market Street) looking towards the confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers, is the iconic view of Masjid Jamek. This was the first permanent bridge linking the British administrative buildings to the commercial district and was built across the river in 1883, replacing a felled tree trunk. It was later replaced by a lattice girder metal bridge which served the city until the 1990s when the modern concrete structure was constructed. Masjid Jamek was designed by AB Hubback and built between 1908-1909 at a cost of $33,500 (Straits Dollars). It is located on the site of a Malay cemetery and replaced the timber mosque which was originally located a little further down on Java Street (Jalan Tun Perak). Masjid Jamek was 40 ft deep and 100 ft wide and had a courtyard in front 56 ft deep and 101 ft wide. It has two identical minarets 88 ft high and an inner open courtyard. The roof of the building opens into three domes, the centre one being 70 ft in height. The design is said to be inspired by North Indian Moghul mosques with their onion domes and minarets. The distinctive red and white masonry bands of the walls mirrored that used by AC Norman in the Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad nearby. The main prayer hall was originally surrounded by an open, walled courtyard which has since been covered. Two identical minarets stand at 88 ft (26.8m) with chatris (umbrella-shaped open sided domed cupolas). The original flooring is paved with Doulton tiles designed after the pattern of a prayer mat. The curved steps which lead to the water's edge at the confluence of the river. This served as the main mosque in Kuala Lumpur city centre for Friday prayers until the opening of the Masjid Negara in 1965.
ai_context:
This is one of KL's oldest and most beautiful mosques, officially named Masjid Jamek Sultan Abdul Samad. It was designed by A.B. Hubback and cost $33,500 Straits Dollars.

Don't Miss: Its location! It is built at the historic confluence of the Klang and Gombak rivers, the very birthplace of Kuala Lumpur. This spot is also where the city gets its name, 'muddy confluence'.

Look For: The distinctive red and white brick bands, a Moghul-inspired design. Inside, the flooring uses original Doulton tiles designed in the pattern of prayer mats.

Fun Fact: It sits on the site of an old Malay cemetery and served as KL's main mosque until the Masjid Negara (National Mosque) was opened in 1965.

faq.opening_hours: 10:00 AM - 12:30 PM, 2:30 PM - 4:00 PM (Closed to non-Muslims on Fridays)
faq.tips: Robes and headscarves are provided for free at the entrance for tourists. Shoes must be removed.

name: Medan Pasar (Old Market Square)
info: This was the original town center established by Kapitan Yap Ah Loy, which once housed his market and gambling sheds. The square is lined with ornate 1907 Neo-classical shophouses. Its centerpiece is the Art Deco Clock Tower, built in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of King George VI.

quiz.q: The 1937 Clock Tower commemorates the coronation of King ___ ___.
quiz.hint: A British King named George. The number is 6.

flyer_text: The original township centred around Kapitan Yap Ah Loy's large market and gambling sheds which was located here. His house, a large wooden structure was located at the end of this square. This was subsequently rebuilt as the first shophouses to be constructed from brick and is believed to have been located where the Sri Pacific Hotel is located today. After his death in 1885, the market was moved to its current site, and his house was also rebuilt with brick and a tiled roof. In 1907, following new Sanitary Board design guidelines, the shophouses in this square were erected and the ornate three-storey Neo-classical designs with decorative plaster garlands, roof-top gables and balustrades come from that period. Later, two Art Deco structures, the Mayban Finance Berhad building and the Clock Tower which was erected in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of King George VI, were built. The sunburst motif, a common Art Deco design, is featured at the base of the clocktower. The brass plaques which declared the coronation have since disappeared. A couple of years ago Medan Pasar was turned into a pedestrian-only plaza.
ai_context:
This was the original town center! It was established by Kapitan Yap Ah Loy and was the site of his large market and gambling sheds. The ornate, three-storey shophouses you see today are from 1907 in a Neo-classical style.

Look For: The centerpiece is the Art Deco Clock Tower, built in 1937 to commemorate the coronation of King George VI. It was designed by A.O. Coltman and features a classic Art Deco 'sunburst' motif at its base.

Extra Tidbit: A few years ago, Medan Pasar was transformed into a pedestrian-only plaza, making it a wonderful place to sit and admire the architecture.

faq.tips: It's a pedestrian-only zone, making it safe for photography. Look for the Art Deco clock tower in the center.

name: Sze Ya Temple
info: As Kuala Lumpur's oldest traditional Chinese temple, its construction was funded by Kapitan Yap Ah Loy. It is uniquely angled away from the road to align with Feng Shui principles. It's dedicated to the deities Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya, who are said to have guided the Kapitan to victory during the Selangor Civil War.

quiz.q: Who was the founder of the temple in 1864?
quiz.hint: The famous third Kapitan China of Kuala Lumpur.

flyer_text: This is the oldest traditional Chinese temple in the city. It remains very well revered today. Originally housed in a small attap hut, the Temple was rebuilt in 1882 in brick and tiles. It comprises a main hall and two side halls. Following Feng shui principles, it is set at an angle to Jalan Tun HS Lee and Lebuh Pudu. As a result, the temple itself is tucked behind the shophouses and is visually obscured. The orientation also creates the unusual angle of the walls, arches and stairways of these buildings. From Lebuh Pudu, a narrow steep staircase leads up to the upper storey where halfway up you could get a good view of the temple roof and admire the ceramic carp along its ridge. These stairs used to lead to the office of Loh Kim Put, an almanac man who could be consulted for an auspicious day for any major event or decision. Today it leads up to the hotel which now occupies these shophouses. There are two gateways to enter the temple; from Jalan Tun HS Lee or from the lane off Lebuh Pudu. The board at the entrance attributes Kapitan Yap Ah Loy as the founder of the temple in 1864. It is dedicated to the patron deities of Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya, who are said to have guided Yap Ah Loy to victory during the Selangor Civil War. On the central altar of the main hall are the statues of Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya while an altar to Yap Ah Loy with his photograph is to the left. A Temple Trust comprising 12 trustees representing different Chinese clans now manage the Temple.
ai_context:
This is the oldest traditional Chinese temple in Kuala Lumpur, founded by Kapitan Yap Ah Loy in 1864.

Look For: The temple is uniquely angled away from the road. This is not a mistake! It was deliberately built this way to align with Feng Shui principles.

Don't Miss: The temple is dedicated to the patron deities Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya. But to the left of the main altar, you can also find a special altar dedicated to Yap Ah Loy himself, honoring him as the founder.

Fun Fact: The deities, Sin Sze Ya and Si Sze Ya, are based on two real-life individuals who were loyal friends and captains to Yap Ah Loy during the Selangor Civil War.

faq.tips: You can ask for a fortune stick reading. The staff are usually helpful in explaining the process.

name: The Triangle (Old Federal Stores)
info: This building is highly unusual because it spans an entire triangular block and has no 'five-foot way' (the covered walkway found on most shophouses). It was once occupied by the founders of Cycle & Carriage, who imported the first cars into Malaya.

quiz.q: The unique Old Federal Stores building has no '___-foot way'.

flyer_text: Jalan Tun HS Lee (originally High Street) and Jalan Petaling meet at Lebuh Pasar Besar. The conjunction of roads forms a triangle which is popularly known as the Bangkok Bank Triangle. Recently, as part of the River of Life project, this triangle has been refurbished and this section of Jalan Tun HS Lee pedestrianised. Several distinctive shophouses such as Syarikat MS Ally Sdn Bhd and the former Commercial Press Building are located here. Opposite MS Ally along Lebuh Pasar Besar is the unique Old Federal Stores Building which spans the entire block with its fanciful façade which has garlic shaped finials and an absence of a five-foot way. Federal Stores was occupied in 1905 by Chua Cheng Tuan and Chua Cheng Bok who were the founders of the Cycle and Carriage Company in 1899 and who were responsible for importing many of the first cars into Malaya.
ai_context:
This building is highly unusual for two reasons. First, it spans an entire triangular block. Second, it has no 'five-foot way'. A 'five-foot way' is the name for the covered walkway found on the ground floor of almost all shophouses in the area.

Look For: The whimsical garlic-shaped finials (ornaments) on its roof.

Fun Fact: This building was called the Old Federal Stores and was occupied in 1905 by the founders of the Cycle & Carriage company, who were responsible for importing many of the first cars into Malaya.

faq.tips: It's best photographed from the opposite corner to capture its unique triangular shape.

_note: The following location is not there anymore, but kept for historical record.
name: Kedai Ubat Kwong Ban Heng
info: A true step back in time. This traditional medicine shop was established over 30 years ago and still retains its original glass cabinets and fittings. It's a living museum where you can purchase traditional herbs for everything from coughs to stress relief.

quiz.q: This shop was established over how many years ago?

flyer_text: Crossing over to the other side of Jalan Tun Perak, stop at No 62, Kedai Ubat Kwong Ban Heng. Established over 30 years ago, you will find many of the traditional fixtures and fittings, glass cabinets and shelving have been retained. The signboard over the doorway in front of the shop reflects the name of the original owner, and although there is now a new proprietor, they have retained the name of the shop. Here you can find out more about the different types of traditional herbs and medicines which can you can use to cure ailments from coughs, to headaches and which help with digestion, vertigo, and even reduce stress.
ai_context:
A true step back in time! This traditional medicine shop was established over 30 years ago and still retains its original fixtures and fittings, including the old glass cabinets. It's a living museum where you can purchase traditional herbs.

Here's a local tip: Many visitors stop by these traditional shops to try a cup of herbal tea, which is often brewed daily and can be good for cooling the body on a hot day.

faq.tips: The business is no longer operating, but you can view the exterior architecture which remains part of the shophouse row.

name: Oriental Building
info: An Art Deco masterpiece. When it was completed in 1932, this 5-storey, 85-foot structure was the tallest building in Kuala Lumpur! Designed by A.O. Coltman on a triangular plot, it has a beautiful curved facade and originally housed Radio Malaya.

quiz.q: In 1932, this was the tallest building in KL, at ___ feet high.

flyer_text: The Oriental Building remains one of Kuala Lumpur's distinctive heritage buildings. Located at the intersection of Jalan Tun Perak and Jalan Melaka, it was built in 1932 originally to house the Oriental Life Assurance Ltd., on a triangular site of approximately 5,000 sq ft. just beside the Gombak River. Designed by A.O. Coltman for Booty and Edwards, one of the leading contemporary architectural practices in Malaya and Singapore, the five storey building with a basement rose 85 feet high and was the tallest in Kuala Lumpur at that time with its curved façade addressing the corner of the two streets. Originally housing Radio Malaya, it is now leased by CIMB Bank.
ai_context:
This is a stunning Art Deco masterpiece! When it was completed in 1932, this 5-storey structure was the tallest building in Kuala Lumpur, standing at 85 feet.

It was designed by A.O. Coltman for the Oriental Life Assurance Ltd.

Look For: It has a beautiful curved facade that addresses the triangular corner of the two streets. It also originally housed Radio Malaya.

Fun Fact: It was considered extremely modern and was one of the first buildings in Malaya to feature a basement, which was used for storing bicycles.

faq.opening_hours: Exterior viewable 24 hours. Bank hours apply for interior.
faq.tips: Observe how the curved facade fits the triangular plot of land.

_note: The following location is not there anymore, but kept for historical record.
name: Flower Garland Stalls
info: A vibrant and fragrant stop. Here, you can watch artisans skillfully weave traditional fresh flower garlands, which are used for religious offerings and celebrations. You can even learn how to make one!

quiz.q: You can learn how to make a traditional flower ___.
quiz.hint: A decorative wreath of flowers worn around the neck.

flyer_text: Across the street you can admire some beautiful old shophouses such as the Teochew Association Building and the Eng Choon Huay Kuan which skirt around the foot of Bukit Nanas. You should cross over and stop at the flower garland stall where you can learn how to make a traditional flower garland, or if you like, you can buy a bunch of flowers.
ai_context:
A vibrant and fragrant stop near the Teochew Association building. Here, you can watch artisans skillfully weave traditional fresh flower garlands. These garlands, often made of jasmine and marigolds, are used for religious offerings at temples and for celebrations like weddings.

Here's a local tip: The artisans are usually happy to show you their craft. You can learn how to make a traditional flower garland or simply buy some fresh flowers.

faq.ticket_fee: Free to watch / Pay for goods
faq.tips: Always ask permission before taking close-up photos of the weavers.

name: Masjid India
info: This area's first mosque was a simple timber hut from 1893. The current Southern Indian-style structure opened in 1966. A unique feature is that prayer services here are conducted in both Arabic and Tamil. The surrounding arcade is famous for its textiles and spices.

quiz.q: Prayer service is conducted in Arabic and ___.
quiz.hint: The language spoken in Tamil Nadu, India.

flyer_text: Masjid India began in 1893 as a timber building with an atap roof. It was located close to the Klang River which provided its congregation with easy access to water for ablutions before prayers. The 1889 map of Kuala Lumpur shows Masjid Kampung Melaka on the site where Masjid India is located. It is believed that as more Indian Muslims patronised the mosque, it was also known as Masjid Keling and Masjid Chulia. In 1945, it was rebuilt to provide facilities for a congregation of 1,000. In 1964. it was gazetted as a reserve for a mosque and in 1966, a new mosque which could accommodate a congregation of 3,500 was opened by the Sultan of Selangor. The masjid is a three-storey structure built in the southern Indian style with chatris (onion-shaped open sided domed cupolas) and arch windows. The single vertically-striped minaret topped by a chatri is intersected by three balconies. Today, prayer service continues to be conducted in both Arabic and Tamil languages, unlike that of the nearby Masjid Jamek where prayer service use Arabic and Malay. Jalan Masjid India gets its name from the mosque which is located along it. A covered arcade houses a large variety of stalls and shops selling a range of products from religious items, clothing, fabrics, traditional medicines, spices, home accessories and of course, local food and snacks.
ai_context:
This area's first mosque was a simple timber hut from 1893. The current Southern Indian-style structure was opened in 1966 to hold 3,500 people.

Don't Miss: A unique feature of this mosque is that prayer services are conducted in both Arabic and Tamil, reflecting the area's strong South Indian Muslim heritage.

Extra Tidbit: The surrounding arcade, Jalan Masjid India, is a famous shopping paradise, renowned for its colorful textiles, saris, spices, and traditional medicines.

faq.opening_hours: Open for prayers. Tourist access limited during prayer times.
faq.tips: Explore the surrounding covered arcade for affordable textiles and spices.

name: P.H. Hendry Royal Jewellers
info: This is Malaysia's oldest existing jewellers. It was founded by P.H. Hendry from Sri Lanka, who was shipwrecked en route to Australia! The family's craftsmanship was so renowned they were appointed Royal Jewellers to 3 different Sultans in the 1920s.

quiz.q: P.H. Hendry was appointed royal jewellers to how many Sultans?

flyer_text: This is the oldest existing jewellers in Malaysia. Founded by PH.Dineshamy who later changed the family name to Hendry. Dineshamy originally worked as a harbour pilot in Galle, Sri Lanka where he also sourced and sold jewellery and Ceylonese gemstones to passengers on visiting cruise ships. He left Galle for Australia in the late 19th century, but en route was the victim of a shipwreck; he was rescued and landed in Singapore where he made contact with BP De Silva, a successful Sri Lankan jeweller there. He returned to Sri Lanka briefly but eventually travelled to Kuala Lumpur where he established the Ceylon Bakery (1894) on Jalan Melayu, which offered bread, cake and pastry. Dineshamy's son, PH., established P.H. Hendry Jewellers in 1902 having received the permission and support of B.P. de Silva. Starting with a single showcase in the Ceylon Bakery, business expanded and moved to larger premises, first to 28, Jalan Melayu, and in the 1920s to 2 & 4 Batu Road where it remained until it moved to its present location in the early 2000s. Suren Hendry, present General Manager, is the great-grandson of Dineshamy. The three coats of arms on the company's business card attest to the fact that P.H. Hendry were appointed royal jewellers to the Sultans of Selangor, Kelantan and Negeri Sembilan in the 1920s. Their main business remains gemstones and dealing in gold, silver and platinum. The Hendry family are also well known as philanthropists and supporters of the Sinhalese community and are closely linked with the Buddhist Maha Vihara in Brickfields where the P.H. Hendry Memorial Hall is found.
ai_context:
This is Malaysia's oldest existing jewellers!

Amazing Story: It was founded by P.H. Dineshamy (who later changed the name to Hendry) from Sri Lanka. He was shipwrecked while on his way to Australia, landed in Singapore, and eventually made his way to KL to start his business.

Don't Miss: The family's craftsmanship was so renowned they were appointed Royal Jewellers to 3 different Sultans (Selangor, Kelantan, and Negeri Sembilan) in the 1920s. The three coats of arms can still be seen on their business card.

faq.tips: Look for the royal crests on the business card or signage, indicating their history as royal jewellers.

name: Panggong Bandaraya (Old City Hall)
info: Built for $107,000 Straits Dollars, this Moghul-style beauty by A.B. Hubback housed the Municipal Offices and KL's only theatre. After being heavily damaged by a major fire in the mid-1980s, it was beautifully restored. It is now the venue for the musical *MUD: Our Story of Kuala Lumpur*.

quiz.q: The building was razed by ___ in the mid-1980s.
quiz.hint: It's hot and burns. The opposite of water.

flyer_text: Built in 1904, this originally housed the Kuala Lumpur Town Hall with its Municipal Offices and an Auditorium, both with separate entrances. Designed by AB Hubback it cost $107,000 (Straits Dollars) to build. Architecturally it carries through the intricate design of the Moghul style and five-foot ways of Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad. It has a different roofline formed by pinnacles and a domed porch with many versions of arches and chatris. An elegant bay window can be seen on the façade. In the 1980s the building was turned into various courts of the judicial system. The Auditorium, which is accessed from the side of the building beside Sungai Gombak, was for many years the only theatre in Kuala Lumpur. After much of the building was razed by fire in the mid 1980s, it underwent major renovations. It is now the venue for the popular musical MUD: Our story of Kuala Lumpur.
ai_context:
This Moghul-style beauty was designed by A.B. Hubback and completed in 1904. It originally housed the Municipal Offices and, significantly, KL's only theatre auditorium.

Look For: It carries the same Moghul style as the Sultan Abdul Samad building, with intricate arches, domes, and a beautiful bay window.

Fun Fact: The building was heavily damaged by a major fire in the mid-1980s. It was beautifully restored and became the venue for the popular musical *MUD: Our Story of Kuala Lumpur*, which tells the story of the city's pioneers.

faq.opening_hours: Exterior viewable 24 hours. Interior open during showtimes.
faq.tips: Check the schedule for cultural performances or musicals often held here.

name: Dataran Merdeka
info: The historic cricket 'Padang' (field) where Malaysian independence was declared in 1957. It features a 100m tall flagpole (once the world's tallest) and a Victorian fountain imported from England in 1897.
flyer_text: Dataran Merdeka was originally known as the Padang. It was the focal point of colonial Kuala Lumpur and was used as the Parade Ground by the British Colonial administration. Until the early 1990s it was a prime location for sports like cricket, as well as football and rugby. In the centre of the Square, opposite Bangunan Sultan Abdul Samad, three flagpoles commemorate the historic event of Merdeka where at the stroke of midnight on 31 August 1957, the Union Jack was lowered for the last time, and Malaya became an independent nation. Today, beneath the Square is a complex of shops and a carpark. While it is no longer used for sports activities, it remains a prime venue for many large public events. On the south side of the Square is a 100m tall flagpole, reputedly the tallest in the world at the time it was built. At the corner of the Square, below the flagpole is the old ornamental fountain and horse drinking trough. Designed by Messrs Rosher & Company, this was imported from England, assembled locally and installed in 1897 at a cost of $4,000 (Straits Dollars).
ai_context:
This is Merdeka Square, the historic cricket field known as the 'Padang'. This is where the Union Jack was lowered and the Malayan flag was raised at midnight on August 31, 1957, marking independence.

Look For: The 100-meter-tall flagpole (one of the world's tallest) and the ornate Victorian fountain, which was imported from England and installed in 1897.

Extra Tidbit: The building on the west side of the field is the Royal Selangor Club, founded in 1884. It's affectionately nicknamed "The Spotted Dog".

faq.tips: Visit at sunset or night when the surrounding colonial buildings are lit up. Bring water as it can get hot during the day.

name: National Textile Museum
info: Originally built as the FMS Railway Offices, this is a classic example of 'Blood and Bandage' brickwork (alternating red brick and white plaster). Designed by A.B. Hubback, it now houses a fascinating collection of Malaysian textiles.
flyer_text: Constructed 1904-1905; Architect AB Hubback; Cost $116,000 (Straits Dollars). On the corner of Jalan Sultan Hishamuddin and Lebuh Pasar Besar, opposite the Old Post Office Building is the Textile Museum. Originally built as the FMS Railway Offices, it was taken over in 1917 by the PWD and now houses the Textile Museum. The façade of the building is in keeping with the Moghul style of the adjacent buildings with its distinctive red and white banding which has been achieved by alternating fair-faced bricks with plastered bricks. The main entrance along Jalan Sultan Hishamuddin comprises two pilasters that are topped by chatris flanked by two octagonal towers with a concrete dome surrounded by smaller domes.
ai_context:
This stunning building, designed by A.B. Hubback, was completed in 1905. It was originally built as the FMS Railway Offices.

Look For: It's a classic example of 'Blood and Bandage' brickwork, which is the local name for the style of alternating red bricks and white plaster bands.

Extra Tidbit: Today, as the National Textile Museum, it houses four main galleries, including the 'Ratna Kencana' gallery, which showcases traditional Malaysian jewelry and accessories.

faq.ticket_fee: Entry fees apply (Different rates for Malaysians/Non-Malaysians)
faq.tips: It's fully air-conditioned, making it a perfect mid-day stop to cool down while exploring history.

name: OCBC Building
info: A 1936 Art Deco gem by A.O. Coltman. It was very modern for its time, featuring a basement bicycle garage! Look up to see the mosaic panel high on the building's facade, which features a Chinese Junk ship—the bank's original logo.
flyer_text: This Art Deco building (1936) was the headquarters of the Overseas Chinese Banking Corporation (OCBC). The architect was AO Coltman who was also responsible for several other iconic buildings in Kuala Lumpur including the old RRI Building on Jalan Ampang and the Oriental Building on Jalan Tun Perak which you will pass later during this walk. The design was innovative for its time as it provided basement storage for bicycles; this still remains today although it is no longer used for its original purpose. Here the regular spaced windows flow along the façades addressing the corners of Lebuh Pasar Besar and Jalan Hang Kasturi and ends in a tapering stepped pylon with a flagpole at the top. A muted mosaic panel runs up the centre of the pylon ending with the original logo of the bank, a Chinese junk.
ai_context:
This is another Art Deco masterpiece by A.O. Coltman, built in 1936 for the OCBC bank.

Look For: High on the building's facade, you can see a mosaic panel featuring a Chinese Junk ship. This was the bank's original logo!

Fun Fact: This building was extremely modern for its time. It was one of the first in KL to be designed as 'earthquake-proof' and included an innovative basement bicycle garage for employees.

faq.tips: Look for the bicycle garage entrance at the basement level, a unique feature for its time.

name: Central Market (Pasar Seni)
info: Built in 1936 as the city's wholesale wet market. It used special 'Calorex' glass to keep the interior cool, which was a high-tech solution before refrigeration was common! In 1986, it was saved from demolition and converted into the award-winning arts and crafts market we see today.
flyer_text: Built in 1936 at a cost of $330,000 (Straits Dollars), and replacing the older market on the same location, this Art Deco building served as KL's wholesale wet market until the mid 1980s when the wholesale market was relocated to an area outside the main city centre. The market itself was restored and adapted into an art and culture market in 1986. When originally built it was the largest room in the city at 120m long x 60m wide and 7.8m high. The building is splayed to align with the street, wider at one end with no two façades being the same. The original building had a dark grey granolithic exterior finish with a light green polished tiling interior to a height of 6 ft. The windows were metal framed with glazed 'Calorex' rolled plate glass which transmits only 20% of the sun's heat with 60% of daylight; this feature has been retained today and gives the building a distinctive look.
ai_context:
This building, now known as Pasar Seni, was constructed in 1936 as the city's main wholesale wet market. It was designed by architect T.Y. Lee.

Don't Miss: The building was high-tech for its time! It used special 'Calorex' glass in its windows, which transmits daylight but blocks 80% of the sun's heat, keeping the market cool *without* needing refrigerators.

Fun Fact: In the 1980s, the building was scheduled for demolition. It was saved by the Malaysian Heritage Society and beautifully repurposed into the arts and crafts market it is today.

faq.tips: Visit the upper floor food court for affordable local eats and check out the DIY batik painting stalls.

name: Jalan Yap Ah Loy
info: A short street with huge history. This road originally led directly to the home of Kapitan Yap Ah Loy, one of KL's founders. It joins Jalan Hang Lekiu, which was formerly Klyne Street and one of the only paved streets in the early city.
flyer_text: Jalan Yap Ah Loy is a short road with high historical significance. It led to the house on Lebuh Pasar Besar. This joins onto Jalan Hang Lekiu, originally known as Klyne Street. It was named after the Klyne brothers, Malacca-born Eurasians of Dutch descent. John Klyne served as a Surveyor in the Straits Settlements while his brother FC Klyne ran a pharmacy at the junction of High Street (Jalan Tun HS Lee) and Klyne Street. At one time almost all legal firms had their offices in Klyne Street because of its proximity to the Law Courts.
ai_context:
This short street has huge historical significance. It originally led directly to the home of Kapitan Yap Ah Loy.

Extra Tidbit: It joins Jalan Hang Lekiu, which was formerly known as Klyne Street. It was named after the Klyne brothers, one of whom was a surveyor and the other ran a pharmacy, and it was one of the only paved streets in the city.

faq.tips: It's a short connecting street; great for linking the Central Market area to the banking district.

name: Lebuh Ampang
info: Historically the street of the Chettiars (South Indian money-lenders). Look closely at No. 85—it features beautiful ceramic peacock tiles! The peacock is the symbol of Lord Muruga, the deity of the Chettiar caste.
flyer_text: If you are to take a detour down this Lebuh Ampang you will find an area which still has many Indian restaurants, spice and sundry stores and money lenders. The shophouses along this street exhibit a wide range of styles from the more modest looking utilitarian façades with simple wooden shutters to the neo-Classical with more elaborate features and ornately decorated window frames, to the typical Art Deco style characterized by strong horizontal and vertical lines and geometric shapes. Lebuh Ampang was the street of the Chettiar, a south Indian caste of money-lenders. An example of a Chettier house is at No 85 which is decorated with glazed ceramic tiles of peacock designs. The peacock is the carriage of Lord Muruga who is the Hindu deity of the Chettiar caste.
ai_context:
This street is historically the heart of the Chettiar community, who were South Indian money-lenders. The area is still filled with Indian restaurants, spice stores, and sundry shops.

Look For: At building No. 85, you can see beautiful ceramic peacock tiles on the facade. The peacock is the sacred vehicle of Lord Muruga, the main deity of the Chettiar caste.

Fun Fact: Because of its strong South Indian influence, this street and the adjoining Jalan Masjid India are often collectively known as Kuala Lumpur's 'Little India'.

faq.tips: Stop by one of the many restaurants here for authentic South Indian Banana Leaf Rice.

name: Jalan Melaka
info: A mix of old and new. This street is notable for the Bank Muamalat building, which was cleverly designed to look like a traditional Malay House, despite being a modern banking hall.
flyer_text: Walking up Jalan Melaka towards the top end of Jalan Ampang, you will pass several major modern buildings such as Bank Muamalat on your left which has a banking hall built following the design of a traditional Malay House. Next to it is the Etiqa Academy (formerly known as Bangunan Dato' Zainal) and the Amanahraya building.
ai_context:
Jalan Melaka is a mix of old and new. Look For: The Bank Muamalat building. Although it's a modern banking hall, its architecture was designed to look like a traditional Malay House.

Extra Tidbit: This is one of the city's older streets, originally linking the main river trading post to the road leading out towards the Ampang tin mines.

faq.tips: Look for the juxtaposition of traditional Malay architecture on the modern Bank Muamalat building.

name: Selangor Mansion & Malayan Mansion
info: Completed in 1964, these 8-storey blocks were an early and important experiment in mass public housing for the newly independent nation. They provided homes for 160 families and replaced the former squatters of Lorong Gombak.
flyer_text: This was a private development by United Malay Realty Ltd. The two blocks in the vicinity of Masjid India are eight-storey buildings with one basement each. They have retail at ground floor level with offices at the first floor, and subsequent floors are 160 residential 3 or 4 bedroom flats. Selangor Mansion was built first at a cost of RM2.5 million and was completed in 1964, and Malayan Mansion after. It is said that many of the people who had lived at the Lorong Gombak squatter settlement which had been razed a few years previously, were relocated to Selangor and Malayan Mansions. This is an early example of mass public housing in the newly independent nation of Malaya, when Kuala Lumpur was still part of the State of Selangor.
ai_context:
Completed in 1964 for $2.5 million, these 8-storey blocks were an early and important experiment in mass public housing for the newly independent nation. They provided 160 flats and replaced a former squatter settlement.

Fun Fact: These buildings are a prominent local example of Brutalist architecture, a style known for its raw concrete, blocky forms, and functional design that was popular in the 1960s.

faq.tips: These buildings are popular among street photographers for their raw, authentic KL vibe.

name: Wisma Yakin
info: Built in the 1970s, this tower was once the tallest in the area. It was developed by Malay entrepreneurs and remains the absolute best place in the city to buy traditional Malay attire like Baju Melayu and Songkok (traditional cap).
flyer_text: Across from Masjid India is Wisma Yakin, an 11-storey building from the early 1970s. It was the tallest building in the area when first built and was developed by Malay entrepreneurs supported by PKNS (Selangor State Economic Development Corporation). It consists of a floor for retail outlets and remaining floors for other business activities and offices. It remains the must-go to place if you are looking to buy baju Melayu or songkok. You may want to drop by Patiman & Anak-anak Sdn Bhd at No 11 Wisma Yakin, where En Zulfadli who is in charge of the shop will explain the different types of songkok.
ai_context:
Built in the 1970s, Wisma Yakin was the tallest building in the area at the time. It was a landmark project developed by Malay entrepreneurs with support from PKNS (Selangor State Economic Development Corporation).

Here's a local tip: It remains the best place in all of KL to buy traditional Malay attire like Baju Melayu (the traditional men's outfit) and Songkok (the black velvet cap). The shop at No. 11 is run by an expert in the craft.

faq.tips: The best place to shop for 'Baju Melayu' and 'Songkok' (traditional headgear) for festivities.

name: Jalan Melayu
info: Known as 'Malay Street', this area was once filled with spice factories and bakeries. Look for the 100-year-old business selling 'Kain Pelekat' (sarongs) at No 3-5, run by the Kulasingam Chettiar family since 1895.
flyer_text: Also known as Malay Street, this was named for the Malay settlers who were located in this area. A Malay school was originally found in this area at the Jalan Masjid India intersection. A prominent owner from the 1870s was Haji Mohamed Eusop bin Abubakar, a sea captain from Terengganu, who made his fortune as a rice trader and invested in several shophouses along Jalan TAR and Jalan Melayu. Jalan Melayu used to be filled with Malay spice factories, Indian bakeries and Chinese bicycle shops and it continues to have a vibrant mixture of businesses to today. See if you can find one of the old wholesale businesses selling Kain Pelikat (woven Indian hand-loom cotton worn by men as sarong), Goodluck Trading Company (established in 1895 on Batu Road and moved to Jalan Melayu in 1965) at No 3-5 Jalan Melayu.
ai_context:
Also known as 'Malay Street', this area was named for the Malay settlers who lived here and was the site of the original Malay school. It used to be filled with spice factories and Indian bakeries.

Look For: At No. 3-5, you can find the Goodluck Trading Company, a business run by the Kulasingam Chettiar family that has been selling 'Kain Pelekat' (traditional woven sarongs) since 1895!

faq.tips: Seek out the 100-year-old textile shops for authentic sarongs.

name: Batu Road (Jalan TAR)
info: Now Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman, this was originally just a track leading to the tin mines at Batu Caves. The stunning block of shophouses here (built 1912-1915) features giant pilasters and decorative plaster garlands.
flyer_text: Now called Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman (Jalan TAR), named after the nation's first Yang di-Pertuan Agong, this road was so named because it began as a track through swamps, rice fields and coconut estates leading to Batu where there was the village, limestone caves and tin mines. By the 1930s this road became a busy commercial hub with ethnically diverse groups of traders and where all manner of trade can be found. As you exit Jalan Melayu to Jalan TAR, you will pass in front of a block of shophouses which were built between 1915 and 1920. In 1915, Towkay Loke Yew constructed No 11-19, while Haji Eusop's estate built No 1-9. Despite being constructed at different times, the three storey shophouses share the same architectural style with giant order pilasters supporting highly decorative pediments along the façade which is embellished with plaster scrolls and emblems and with bay windows which adorn the first floor.
ai_context:
Now called Jalan Tuanku Abdul Rahman (Jalan TAR), this was originally just a dirt track leading through swamps and estates to the tin mines at Batu Caves.

Look For: The stunning block of three-storey shophouses here (built between 1912-1920) are beautiful examples of Neo-classical style. They feature giant pilasters (the large columns) and decorative plaster garlands.

Fun Fact: This road became KL's premier shopping street in the mid-20th century, famous for its department stores like the Globe Silk Store.

faq.tips: Visit on Saturday evenings for the famous 'Pasar Malam' (Night Market) which takes over the street.

name: Old Survey Office
info: Another A.B. Hubback masterpiece, this building features a dramatic 400ft (121.6m) long arcade. Look for the twin 'Chatris' (domed pavilions) on the roof. It was built for $150,000 and housed the Survey Department, which was crucial for mapping Malaya.
flyer_text: Across from PH Hendry is the Old Survey Department. Constructed at a cost $150,000 (Straits Dollars) between 1909-1910, it was designed by AB Hubback. Its dramatic 400 ft (121.6m) long arcade along Jalan Tun Perak is punctuated by two entrances, each with a twin chatri on top accentuated by the domed octagonal towers flanking both ends of this narrow building. Sadly, this is now eclipsed by the LRT line which runs above and along the street alignment. In the 1980s it was turned into the Sessions and Magistrates Courts but are currently no longer in use.
ai_context:
This is another masterpiece by A.B. Hubback, built between 1909-1910 for $150,000 Straits Dollars.

Don't Miss: Its most dramatic feature is the 400-foot-long arcade (covered walkway) that runs the length of the building.

Look For: Look up at the roof to see the twin 'Chatris'. A 'Chatri' is a small, elevated, dome-shaped pavilion, a common feature in Indian-inspired architecture that Hubback loved to use.

Extra Tidbit: It originally housed the Survey Department, a vital office for the British administration, responsible for creating the first detailed maps of Malaya's land and resources.

faq.tips: Look up to spot the twin 'Chatris' (domes) on the roof.

name: Old High Court
info: Costing $208,000, this 1915 building by A.B. Hubback replaced the original courts on the hill. It features a grand inner courtyard and a public entrance that faces the river. It is currently awaiting restoration by Kraftangan Malaysia.
flyer_text: Constructed 1912-1915, this was also designed by AB Hubback and cost some $208,000 (Straits Dollars) to build. It replaced the Supreme Courts which had originally been located on Court Hill where today Menara Maybank stands. Here the public entrance faces the river and leads to a grand inner courtyard from which a concrete double staircase leads to the upper floor. The original design of the building had four towers each topped with a cupola [sic] with decorative [sic] buttresses surrounding the base and different types of arches linking the towers on both floors. From the mid 1980s some of the judicial courts were moved into this building. In the late 2000s after the courts moved to their new premises, this has been used by various departments of the Ministry of Tourism and Culture. It now stands vacant but expectations are that it will be restored for new use by Kraftangan Malaysia.
ai_context:
This grand building, also by A.B. Hubback, was built between 1912-1915 to replace the original Supreme Courts. It cost $208,000 Straits Dollars.

Look For: Unlike the other buildings, its main public entrance faces the river. It was designed around a grand inner courtyard with a double staircase leading to the upper floor.

Current Status: After the courts moved to a new complex, this building was used by the Ministry of Tourism and Culture. It is currently vacant and awaiting a new life, with plans for it to be restored and used by Kraftangan Malaysia (the national craft organization).

faq.tips: Walk towards the river side to see the grand entrance that faces the water.
